headline: We stay busy, but it's a rewarding place to work!
pros:
We have incredible healthcare benefits!!! I feel like St. Jude looks out for my health and well-being. I love having an onsite pharmacy and clinic; it makes it way easier for me to keep appointments during the day. 

I respect our administrative leadership's efforts to better increase and highlight diversity and inclusion. Our workforce is very diverse, but it's nice to see that it's increasingly celebrated. In the past year we've formed the women's + allies resource group and the Black employees + allies resource group. They, along with our PRIDE group, are doing some incredible things on campus. I feel lucky to be a part of these groups and help celebrate our diversity.

We mandated the vaccine!!! I feel valued and safe and also very proud that we are taking steps to protect our patients and their families, as well as each other and each other's families. 

St. Jude churns out some powerful and world-changing research. Our resources and our faculty are top-notch; I am always so proud to be in Memphis and a part of this incredible institution. Working in HR, I love to be a part of hiring, training, and elevating employees. I believe that we are equipped and empowered to be some of the best.
cons: It's a pandemic, so we are BUSY. We're tired and stressed. We've been forced to make some changes in some of our departments to better handle the pandemic. Some of us have transitioned to remote work (guess that's not really a con for most people though). But I feel like I have been supported by this organization even on the rough days and I look forward to when I can return to complaining about something way less serious, like our Starbucks line being too long.

headline: A pandemic paradise...
pros:
During this challenging time, St Jude leadership has kept us updated and informed regarding ways to keep our families and ourselves safe. More importantly, we are being supported and instructed in keeping our hospital safe for the children and families who need us right now. 
We are all given good masks (and required to wear them), tested regularly, provided the cleaning supplies and the environment we need to be as safe as we can be. 

We also hear regular words of appreciation and encouragement from the CEO on down the chain, for our efforts to keep our campus safe.
cons: There are some people in every population who take public health issues more seriously than others. Unfortunately, we have a few people who do not follow the suggested health and safety guidelines, but most do.

headline: A great alternative to industry or university for science lovers
pros:
1. More stable compare to scientist positions in industry or universities (where you can retire from if you really want to)
2. Decent compensation plus great benefits, particularly when taking into account the relatively lower living expenses ($350,000 for a 4b, 4b mansion in the city outskirts, which are safe and pretty)
3. Great infrastructure and core facilities: almost the only limitation is your capability and maturity. Depending on the group joined, one can get either more academic (publishing high impact paper) or industry like experience (R&D, GMP, clinical trials) or both.
cons:
1. Talented scientist easily stands out and may become complacent.
2. Prepare to commute 30-50 min to downtown from Germantown or Collierville (there is no good public school downtown)
3. You have to be creative with your exit plan (assuming you plan to leave at some point). Research staff is NOT considered a stepping stone to tenure track positions in universities (unless negotiated before entering), although transiting to industry is relatively easy.

headline: Mission, Leadership, Benefits...This is the best place to work!
pros: Having worked in various industries over the years, St. Jude has the best response when you think, "why do I want to go to work today?"   The St. Jude mission says it all, and when you combine that with great leadership and the best benefits package I have had, it puts St. Jude Children's Research hospital at the very top of the list of places to work.
cons: The only negative I can say is the location in downtown Memphis.  This is not really due to the area, but due to the 40 minute drive I have from my home in east Shelby county.

headline: Awesome work community
pros:
The work community at St. Jude is a wonderfully collaborative and friendly group.  In 14 months on campus, I have not encountered anyone who isn't dedicated to the hospital's mission and making St. Jude the environment possible. You can turn to anyone on campus, even those outside of your own department, for help. Collaborative projects are encouraged and supported. 

The administration and departmental managers encourage personal development and education, whether it's attending talks, learning new techniques, or earning a degree. Seminars, poster sessions, and talks are open to all employees and tuition assistance for formal coursework is available. There are also a lot of mobility options on campus for both upward and lateral transfers, as well as shifting job tracks between clinical, research, and administration.

St. Jude is committed to keeping it's community happy and retaining talent. The salaries and benefits are the best in the area and we get plenty of fun perks beyond the standard healthcare and retirement benefits.

It's clear that the administration actually cares about its employees. There's a great deal of transparency in goals, planning, and reasoning, and the administration communicates with the rest of the community regularly and clearly. New processes and changes are clearly thought out before they are implemented and the reasoning behind them is explained to the community at large. Particularly with regard to the current public health concerns, the changes that have been made to keep the campus safe and healthy have been well-designed, rolled out in an organized fashion, and communicated clearly to the community.
cons: I haven't encountered any yet.

headline: LOVE MY JOB!!!!!!!!!!!!!
pros: St. Jude is a great place to work. The feeling of family throughout the institution and great leadership team makes you want to come to work and do your best everyday!
cons: I have NO Cons to report.

headline: Started off great but last few years have been a struggle
pros: The patients and their families make every day worth it. The benefits are really good. The pay is semi-competitive.
cons: There's VERY little diversity amongst the staff which I've heard from some family makes them disheartened (like you could count on one hand how many non-Caucasian doctors or NPs/PAs there are). Administration had definitely moved towards a "you should be lucky to work here" stance with employees if there are ever any complaints from staff. The pay is significantly less than most other hospitals in the area, and the only things that makes it competitive are the benefits. There's very little room for advancement at the company if you don't know (or aren't related to) someone higher up in the company.

cons: The scheduling flexibility and work-from-home options are still a bit old fashioned, but I think the goal is to keep folks as connected to the mission as possible, and that means being on campus.

headline: St. Jude truly is a great place to work!
pros:
The culture at St. Jude is something extremely special. There are doctors, researchers and administrative professionals all on one campus, working towards one goal:  to advance cures for pediatric catastrophic diseases. There is no question why we are here. We know the mission and the purpose at St. Jude, no matter if you're treating the patients directly or serving those that do. 
The benefits go further than the incredible health/dental/eye insurance packages we offer. Special events like Judestock (an outdoor concert with food trucks galore), Fashionista (discounted department store  goodies with proceeds that directly benefit St. Jude) and St. Jude Farmer's Market (includes fresh fruits and vegetables grown from our very own garden) are just of the few on-campus perks of working at St. Jude. 
I believe our President and CEO, Dr. James Downing, has an incredible vision for the future of St. Jude. He believes in investing in his employees and listening to what they have to say.

headline: There's a reason this place is consistently voted a great place to work
pros:
Excellent benefits - 7% 403b contribution (as in, they GIVE you cash money) -- you can contribute whatever you want. Full health (90%), vision, and dental coverage. So many vacation days I'm now at a point where I have to take time off. Every high-tech toy a scientist could want. Oh, and free parking!

But the real reason to work at St. Jude is the work that we do here. There is one (1) cafeteria on campus, by design, so all the doctors and scientists and patient families all converge. Even if you have a terrible day in the lab/office/etc., you take one look at those beautiful babies and are reminded to get back to the fight. 

You will never have a day where you question the mission. You will always feel like you are contributing to something great.

headline: Hiding daily from bullying...dont apply if you can help it!
pros: The patients are well taken care of and treated like royalty! Dr. Downing is the best! Thats the best and only Pro about this place...
cons: I have been here for quite some time. Ive made complaints about the mistreatment received and shown to not only staff but the management that has recently been hired has fallen right into the riff-raff. She's right in the middle of the gossip groups. Spreading lies and creating tremendous turmoil amongst us. The new system that was brought in has made it harder for us to do our jobs because NO ONE in this office is trained to use it properly. This is not only a hindrance for me to do my job- which I can do effortlessly- but it creates an issue for other people in the office to complain and gossip because they cannot work do to the fact they don't know HOW to work. You've hired incompetent people. From the entry level, to the top management in this office. I see so many "immediate termination" issues daily. Coworkers discussing patient info in front of patient family's, employees outside on personal cell phones all day, name calling with profane labels and racial slurs, security even allowed a car in with weed smoke and loud music onto the campus!! Amongst other things that management turns a blind eye to to keep it off their desk. HR knows most of this but won't do anything about it because its been documented before and hasn't changed. Im typing this review right now sitting next to 3 employees discusssing another employees FMLA status and why she needs to be fired and how they "wish she wasn't here." The employee they are talking about in an exemplary worker and works circles around us all...even when she misses days. She works sick, has lost her dad, her mother in law, her home amongst other issues and still manages to come and work tirelessly. But they are just bullying her with management looking right past it. Thats just one example of how much people take from others here and nothing is done. There are many other examples. The public doesn't know the darkside of this once beloved institution and rightfully so....however, if we can't get the help we need here, From the inside, outside help has to be sought and used. I love my job, and I give 200% daily all while working with a debilitating illness that keeps me struggling to stay encouraged, but I do so. But to deal with bullying, scrutiny, disrespect, name calling, incompetence, hearsay, laziness, and discrimination from this place daily is very tiring and cruel. Fix this...before it hurts this place!!!

headline: Honestly

You come in with these high expectations, but quickly realize it is still a business at the end of the day. It's a great outer façade, but the inner structure needs a lot of rebuilding. Everyone here is really smart so it's super competitive with a lot of my co-workers and certain work areas are extremely stressful because of management and how they treat/talk to employees. I can only speak for my specific department.  Also, because people love St. Jude so much and don't want to retire, career advancement opportunities are slim especially in certain departments so just be ok with being stagnant for a while if you don't look for opportunities outside of your area.  A lot of people make St. Jude their lives and some of them expect you to make work your life as well.

headline: Meaningful Mission and People who Care
pros:
Best mission ever - save children's lives regardless of who they are, what they believe, the color or their skin, and whether or not their parents can pay.  What mission could possibly be more inspiring?
Despite (or maybe because of) being a non-profit, St. Jude has an attitude of doing what it takes to get results.  This means they don't skimp on cutting edge technology and that philosophy trickles down to non-research areas.  We get the tools we need.   The key words there are "tools" and "needs".    My department is  very aware  our budgets come from donor dollars so we aren't frivolous, but we do make sure people have what they need to get their work done. 
Dr. Downing  (our CEO) makes many/regular opportunities to communicate our strategies, goals, and progress.  He isn't afraid to discuss ideas and answer questions.  He is also open to explaining the reasoning behind our strategic plan.  
There is a lot of change going on, it's exciting.
cons:
Quality o f management is inconsistent across departments,  resulting in pockets of low morale and low engagement.   There are ongoing attempts to improve this situations , for example, they started a "Leadership Academy" for managers as well as directors, but it will take time to know whether or not it has helped.
Due to fast growth, our cubicle/office space is TINY  - also St. Jude puts it money where it's important - into spaces for patients and their families.  If you are a person who wants a large office or large cubicle, you won't find it here - but we have great outdoor space and an awesome cafeteria. 
There is a lot of change going on , it's a little overwhelming.

You can take your project to the furthest reach of your imagination, which is an extraordinary feeling. St. Jude also has ways of relocating you to a better working environment.
cons: Not all labs and managers are the same. If you are in a lab where your boss is treating you very badly, you often feel stuck. While St. Jude has ways of helping you to relocate to a new lab, it can feel like you have no support.

headline: Very Supportive and Appreciative Environment

Compared to other opportunities, a research position at St. Jude is more secure and provides better benefits and slightly higher compensation. It's also an extremely collaborative, non-competitive environment.
cons: At times, there is a lot of red tape and things can be slow-moving (ordering supplies, new equipment, office space, etc).  There also is a lack of space and a ton of shared space, which is not always ideal in science. However, a new research is currently being built so hopefully this will solve some of these problems.

headline: Administrative Specialist

HR works for management not staff.   Lots of backstabbing and throwing coworkers under the bus.  St. Jude is just like Oz - looks amazing on the outside but is really only smoke and mirrors.  If you are not management or faculty, you run a high risk of not making it more than a year or 2.

headline: Less rewarding researching career with PhD
pros: Great cause and saving lives of innocent kids. Great environment for research.
cons:
Researchers are the major contribution for the success of discoveries in the research and finding cure for patients. These researchers had PhDs and several years of postdoctoral experience. They have to work on weekends and after hours most of the time for a successful completion of experiments, findings/discoveries. 
But recently I found that people with just master’s and 1-3 years of experience are well paid in non-research areas like fund raising, information systems and other administrative jobs with mostly 8-5 work schedule. I know the motivation of the organization is not commercial but there is huge biased in the pay structure & benefits among the employees of different departments. Also, the benefits for the employees at higher level are much better, on top of high pay scales, such as tuition fee reimbursement for their children and other perks.

In addition, the researchers have very limited opportunity to grow to a higher level and be an independent researcher as they don't support the staff to write grants.
I joined the organization with lot of hopes and motivation to work for the innocent kids and their survival. But the organization focus is mostly driven towards fundraising and getting attention in the media to get more funds.

headline: Working at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital
pros:
Global leadership as one of the world's premier pediatric cancer research centers, whose mission is to find cures for children with cancer and other catastrophic diseases through research and treatment.
Cutting-edge research in understanding the molecular, genetic and chemical bases of catastrophic diseases in children; identifying cures for such diseases; and promoting their prevention.
Outstanding clinical research studies in gene therapy, bone marrow transplantation, chemotherapy, biochemistry of normal and cancerous cells, radiation treatment, blood diseases, resistance to therapy, viruses, hereditary diseases, influenza, pediatric AIDS, psychological effects of catastrophic illnesses, and the long-term outcomes of its patients. 
Top leadership, world-renowned scientists, physicians and support staff. Excellent continuing education career advancement opportunities. An environment that promotes the health, well-being and work-life balance of employees, recognizes and supports exceptional performance. 
St. Jude Children's Research Hospital is growing at the speed of scientific discovery and advancement. There are and will be many opportunities for those with a passion for excellence and an inner drive to work hard to help fulfill the mission to globally "Find cures and save lives".
cons: After almost a decade, I can say that it is still an honor and a privilege to serve in this organization, and am truly humbled and amazed every day at the work that goes on here.

Most of the upper management seems to be content with clashing over responsibility as well as shifting it. This had trickled down to a lot of their subordinates causing communication failure to become an accepted part of an employee's workday.  

Management too often becomes part of the problem and not the solution by enacting most changes and guidelines as a form of spin or protection.  Forcing most of the lower staff to spend more time playing the same game and less on their actual jobs. 

Job-related training is often scarce, off focused and last minute. 

Priorities here are mainly seen from one viewpoint making unrealistic goals and expectations a daily norm. Great work is only rewarded with more hard work.

headline: Management issues cloud the St Jude mission
pros:
1.  Diverse community of talented physicians and scientists 
2. Good benefits
cons:
1.  Terrible management.  Management is the most demoralizing thing about working at St Jude.  Often employees are trapped between a direct supervisor and a "dotted line" supervisor, and when desires clash, or one feels that the employee is more loyal to the other, the employee loses out.  This is a no win situation that does not seem to get remedied.  
2.  No training or managerial oversight.   As a new employee, it is not an unreasonable expectation to be provided with a list of applications and tools that need to be requested (and even how to go about placing such a request) so that one can fully perform his/her job.  Training should also fall under a Director or Manager's responsibility.  Being told "go ask ______," is not training.  It's very discouraging to me to see my employees were not trained well because training is contingent on who the "trainee" was that was responsible for imparting bits of knowledge.  The lack of training in the day-to-day mechanics of clinical research is not setting this institution up for success. 
3.  Inequity in employee treatment.  The work environment at SJ is very Orwellian:  "All are created equal, but some are more equal than others."

headline: Truly a great place to work!
pros: I can say that they have the BEST medical/dental/vision insurance policies of any organization where I've worked, in Memphis.  The Administration at SJ really wants all employees to have work/life balance.  To assist employees with this, they have a first class gym, on campus, with free membership to all employees.  They offer group exercise programs or, you may choose to take an afternoon bike ride with other employees.  And, the best surprise of all, we will occasionally receive "additional" days off on major holidays.  Since Christmas is on a Monday this year (2017) we were also given the Friday prior as an additional holiday.  And, they just increased the amount of vacation you get!
cons: Wow, I cannot think of any cons about working at SJ.  When I first began working at SJ, it sometimes would upset me if I saw a sick child.  Now, after fully understanding the mission and seeing the ongoing efforts the doctors and researchers, I know SJ is the BEST place for the children facing these challenges.

headline: Perfect place to enhance and cultivate your career!
pros: So many opportunities and St. Jude allows and encourages innovative ideas and at the same time a lot of flexibility for home-life balance. I have had great bosses here at St. Jude---understanding and caring.  So many amenities are offered as well as fantastic benefits.  It is amazing to be in such a medical mecca with so much going on in the healthcare arena here.  Also, you can't beat the low cost of living in Memphis, especially in a city with lots to do and with so much southern hospitality.  Can't beat the barbeque anywhere in the world!
cons: I disagree about Memphis not being a good place to raise children!  Memphis is my home.  I was raised her and have raised 3 children here and I think Memphis is a wonderful place to raise children---as long as they have wonderful parents to guide them.

headline: Administration
pros: The mission! Everyone contributes in some way to finding cures for and treating our patients. Everyone is encouraged to contribute ideas for making St. Jude a better place both for patients and employees. Our benefits are phenomenal. They include 3 weeks vacation the first year of employment and 5 weeks  after 10 years; affordable health, eye and dental care; free, onsite workout facilities; employee appreciation events; fantastic cafeteria and 2 Starbucks kiosks; retirement plan (St. Jude automatically contributes a portion of your salary regardless of whether or not you contribute) and tuition assistance.
cons: The institution has grown and we have expanded so much that it can be hard to connect with colleagues who are now on the other side of campus.

headline: St Jude Chidlren's Research Hospital
pros: I've worked at St. Jude over 10 years and it's the best place I've ever worked.  The benefits are great, the respect from senior management is visible and felt everyday--from walking the halls with us to listening to and encouraging ideas from any and all staff members. Recognition and rewards are a high priority at St. Jude--for a job well done as well as for activities in the community (volunteers, races, etc.) St. Jude has truly been a blessing to my life.
cons: The campus is growing every day! Parking is sometimes an issue and getting from one side of the 60+ acre campus to the other for meetings can be a challenge.  But I look at it as a way to get my Activity Points/Steps in, to help me stay healthy--which is also encouraged here!

headline: Making a difference every day in the lives of others
pros: Best part of working at St Jude is being part of a wonderful mission to find cures and save children and share that knowledge with the world. I am very proud to have worked for St Jude for nearly 18 years and it is only getting better.

The cure rates are getting better all the time and the scientists and doctors will not stop until they are 100%. The families feel better knowing that by bring their children here they have given them every chance possible to save their lives.

headline: Manager

headline: Good place to work but still has drawbacks
pros: Good health coverage, beautiful campus, college tuition program is great and increased every so often.  I was hired in making 8K less than I had previously but was brought back up to my same salary within 3 1/2 years.
cons: I was informed when interviewed that they needed an person for a faculty member that went through this position very frequently and that they wanted someone who was able to tolerate being yelled out, manage frequent temper tantrums, bad attitude, difficult to work for, went through assistants frequently, etc.   I found out within the first week that this does go on quite frequently in the office.  What I found most interesting about the situation is that it is tolerated at all - 50 years ago, maybe, but now it is quite strange.  And it is such common knowledge that the departmental director, admin director, and directors/faculty of other departments are aware of this behavior, frequently discussed, joked about even, but is still found to be acceptable .  I am not aware of any other faculty members behaving this way, but I still think it's is ultimately unacceptable behavior for a grown, educated adult.  And also ultimately unacceptable for such a large and world known corporation to allow this behavior as "acceptable" for so long and continue to do so.  Ultimately, I like working for St. Jude and currently have no plans to leave - but a little less daily stress would be nice.

headline: Employment with a sense of purpose
pros:
There are innumerable benefits to working with St. Jude. However, I will attempt to highlight some that I find to be most important, as I view Glassdoor as an opportunity to provide real insight to potential employees. Also, I want to clarify that my bias will be towards clinical care, as I am a registered nurse. I have no first hand knowledge of other areas.  So, as they say, caveat emptor.

First and foremost, there is our guiding mission.  "No child should die in the dawn of life." The work that we do on a daily basis does indeed help save lives.  I have seen advances in treatment and outcomes first hand.  It is slow and incremental, but it's there.

Our benefits are better than the norm. I've compared our benefits to other institutions over the last five years, and dollar for dollar, ours are better.  I'm sure that there are exceptions to that, based on personal needs and familial situations, but on average I'd pit our benefits package against almost any employer in Memphis. 

Work/life balance.  12 hour shifts can be brutal, but our ability to self-schedule helps ensure that we can have the time we need to recover.  There are instances where changes have to be made, and we don't always agree with them.  BUT, that's a risk you run with any employer.  We also have the added advantage of paid holidays, personal time, PTO and sick time to supplement our days away from the job.  Many of us take that for granted, but for most hospitals give employees less time away.  And they typically have ZERO paid holidays.

Non-clinical employment opportunities.  There comes a time in our lives (as nurses) where the bedside is no longer an option.  It could be age, physical condition, or mental fatigue.  Regardless, there are numerous options away from the clinical setting for those that would like a change.  Yes, there is competition. No, there aren't always positions when we want them.  But in life, patience is a virtue.

Lastly, I would say a sense of camaraderie. This is both a pro and a con. Many shifts (again, I am speaking solely to nursing) and units feel very much like family.  We can be very tight knit, supporting one another in times of distress, whether it's professional or personal.  We celebrate triumph, commiserate with one another during defeat, and we mourn our losses as one. I am proud to work on my unit, and I call many of my colleagues friends.  I've not felt the same in previous roles, so I embrace it.
cons:
It would be dishonest of me to omit the flaws that I see (personally), so I'll outline them as best i can. 

As I mentioned, there is a sense of camaraderie and of family.  With that, though, comes the formation of cliques and aloof behavior.  It waxes and wanes, but it does happen.  Often, we are able to "self-correct", but sometimes it leads to alienation of new employees.  It's something of which we must all be mindful.  And like most families, we have our share of dysfunctional family members who are negative, loud, or downright cantankerous. We are but human.

Salary. I'm sure I've never met anyone who was completely satisfied with their compensation package. That said, I sometimes feel as if we aren't as competitive as we could be.  We as an organization set ourselves apart from other hospitals in most regards, but then choose to use local market comparisons for pay.  It seems counterintuitive if the objective is to recruit premier talent from across the country.  Adjusting for cost of living, we are still paid less than nurses at similar institutions with similar prestige (UCSF, Dana Farber, CHOP, and Stanford to name a few). 

Paid Time Off. As I previously stated, I feel like we have sufficient time off.  The con is that we continue to place time off in multiple buckets (sick, family sick and vacation).  My preference would be to see my current time off placed into a single PTO bucket, for use at my discretion.  While I'm sure there are those who use sick time on a consistent basis, I know a number of individuals who are no longer accruing sick time because they have reached the maximum allowed.  My concern is that other entities that have made the transition from Sick/Vacation route to PTO have decreased the overall benefit, and that would be detrimental. 

Limited advancement potential. While there are a number of roles away from the clinical area for nurses, there is limited upward potential within inpatient nursing.  Each unit has 6 coordinators, and there are only four manager roles.  It can be discouraging if you desire any sort of upward progression.  Couple that with poor to non-existent career guidance, and you have created an environment that encourages one to look outside the hospital for advancement.  

Shift differentials. A common complaint is the loss of shift differential for time off. If a dayshift employee takes time away from work (vacation/sick/personal time), then they are paid their normal salary.  A night shift employee who takes time away is "penalized" for taking time away, as the 20% night shift differential is not paid on unworked hours.   I'm also aware that the shift differential is intended to compensate employees for the hardships placed on shift workers who must adapt to unusual working hours.  My personal feeling is that it's equally difficult to "flip-flop" from a night to day circadian rhythm and that the hardship of shift work doesn't end just because I've chosen to take a day off.  I would also point out that it is not unprecedented.  The federal government currently pays shift workers differential for unworked hours, as do many state governments.  Additionally, there are entire industries that do as well.  

All that being said, none of the cons I've listed are deal breakers for me.  I only include the cons to illustrate both sides to the same coin.

headline: Dream Job at a Life-Changing Institution
pros: Working at St. Jude was a dream job for me that I knew I wanted, but wasn't sure if it would/could work out for me.  The actual job posting/application/interview/job offer process took a little longer than I expected, but I can honestly say it was well worth the wait!  The recruiter was responsive to my questions and very informative with St. Jude information during the process.  Since I lived out of state, I had two phone interviews initially and then a campus visit interview.  After accepting the job offer and beginning employment, I've had several people ask me what it's like to work at St. Jude.  Their impression is that working at St. Jude would be depressing and very difficult.  While we do have very serious cases of childhood diseases being treated here, I can honestly say that St. Jude is a place of hope.  I feel much more hope in the corridors than I do depression.  Reality is different at St. Jude than any other employer where  I've worked.  Having the opportunity to work with amazing, brilliant people who are diligently working on cures for amazing, brilliant children who are on a difficult journey is truly a rewarding experience.  St. Jude Children's Research Hospital is a life-changing place.....for everyone.
cons:
The recruitment process took a bit longer than expected (but worth the end result).
No other cons thus far.

headline: Truly is a Best Place to Work
pros: The mission alone is a reason to work here. However, St. Jude also has many other attributes that are attractive to employees. It offers a good benefits package and seems to value employee input. While other organizations I've worked for have asked for employees' opinions, they have disregarded them after receiving feedback. St. Jude truly listens. It also offers professional development opportunities and an employee recognition program. The hospital also emphasizes employee physician and mental health through an on-site, free fitness center, bikes to ride across campus, mobile mammograms, and free yearly health screenings. There are also health incentives.
cons: The downtown location can be congested during commuting hours. Surrounding neighborhood is uneven, but there are long-range plans to improve that. The hospital has great security, though, and secure parking. Cafeteria lines can be long at lunch. Building names can be confusing.

headline: The BEST place to work
pros:
At St. Jude, I'm able to use my skills and energy to help save the lives of children around the world. Every person who works here -- from the people who clean the offices to the people who work in the labs to the people who cook the food -- know that they play a role in a much larger mission. That knowledge gives meaning and fulfillment to us all. 

At the head of our organization is Dr. James Downing, who constantly works to find new ways to connect with employees and families alike. He is a great communicator, who makes a concerted effort to interact with staff through Town Hall meetings, eating lunch with employees in the cafeteria, and attending many events where he can meet and talk with staff. 

I truly believe that St. Jude allows me to make a contribution to something that will reverberate long after I am gone.
cons: The only downside of working at St. Jude is that it is a fairly long drive each morning.

headline: Interview Process and Initial Months
pros:
The interview process with St. Jude was smooth and enjoyable.They were very organized with all of the planning (e.g., scheduling and booking travel, meetings with faculty, etc) and very informative when it came to learning more about both the institution and the city of Memphis. The faculty and staff were open, kind, and genuine throughout the interview process. Meetings were set up with faculty who were very relevant to my interests and future collaborations. 

St. Jude was INCREDIBLY helpful in assisting with the cross country transition and helping me get settled in Memphis. 

In my first few months of working here, St. Jude has completely lived up to (and in some cases exceeded) the expectations I had before starting here. As others have stated, they truly do seem to care about their employees and their input - which I think is often rare in a hospital/research setting. There is a feeling of a bigger mission and purpose within the institution, and for the most part, it is a mission that goes far beyond our individual pursuits and accomplishments. This is also very refreshing in a research setting.
cons: I had to do some minimal follow up with individuals/companies during the transition and moving process to ensure things were on the right track - but this again was minimal.

headline: Desirable workplace if you are in the right job
pros: St. Jude is highly respected, both in the city of Memphis but throughout the United States as a whole. It feels good to work for an employer that is held in such high regard. The benefits are St. Jude are really pretty good – the 403b retirement plan (with 7% contribution by St. Jude!) and the medical, dental and vision benefits are also really nice too. The people here are generally nice and most of them are happy to be here. St. Jude is growing and is financially healthy, which bodes well for future employment and growth opportunities.
cons:
Unfortunately, like most employers, St. Jude has it’s flaws. In my particular position in Enterprise Informatics, I am the primary (well, really the only) resource in my area. If an issue arises, I pretty much have to respond to resolve the problem. Essentially, that makes me a resource that is on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days per week, 365 days per year. Of course, it really isn’t reasonable for someone to be on-call 24/7/365 but that is basically what it feels like and management has pretty much admitted that is the reality of my particular position. It was pretty disappointing to learn that being on-call all the time was the reality and the expectation of management, as that wasn’t mentioned in the job description when I applied and it wasn’t mentioned to me as a requirement of the job when I was interviewing for the position. This is a pretty big job requirement to somehow get left out of the job description and not get mentioned when interviewing candidates. How does it manage to get left out? A candidate should not find this out after accepting the job and beginning to work at St. Jude.

The biggest negative about being the only resource in my area (and being on-call 24/7/365 as a result) is that it makes it difficult to mentally separate myself from work, even after leaving St. Jude for the day. It leaves me wondering what I would do if I am out to eat with friends or family or at a movie theater and suddenly receive a call for help – will I be able to respond in a reasonable amount of time? What is actually a reasonable amount of time in my situation? Should I even go out to eat or to see a movie under these circumstances? Do I need to clear my plans with my boss before going? I certainly don’t want there to be an expectation that I have to clear my personal life & weekend plans with my boss, as that encroaches too much on an individual’s personal life to be reasonable. I haven’t been told that this is the case, of course, because no one in management has ever made it clear what the expectations are for responding to a call situation.

 I also have to think about it whenever I am considering traveling on weekends outside of my normal work hours. What happens if I receive a call while I am away? Will I be able to find a business, hotel, etc that has Wi-Fi? What if I am on the interstate or highway miles from any place with usable Wi-Fi? Again, do I need to clear my plans with my boss before going? What happens if I cannot respond for whatever reason (bad cell service, lack of WiFi access, etc.)? Will I be reprimanded? Will I be written up? Will I be fired? The expectations of management and of St. Jude as an organization have never really been clear in this regard. There are lots of little details like this that I am forced to think about because of the constant on-call aspect of my job, when I really should be free to focus on enjoying my life outside of work. Since there isn’t a clear separation between the two (work and personal life), it is sometimes difficult to enjoy my life outside of St. Jude.

While it would be true to say that I don’t receive a call every night or even every week but it is still a difficult position because no one can truly be available to respond to an issue all of the time. Life happens and sometimes people aren’t available. What happens when I cannot respond? I imagine that if I told my manager that I couldn’t respond, then he would try to deal with it himself (I have no true backup, so technically my manager would almost certainly be my backup). The problem with that idea is that he doesn’t truly know some of my work well enough to fix a lot of issues by himself. He would probably need my help resolving a decent percentage of system issues, which would mean me trying to walk him through resolving the problem over the phone. Of course, in that situation I might as well have taken the call and resolved the issue myself in the first place. So, relying on a backup person (ie, my manager) to provide me with some down time probably wouldn’t work out very well.

It is an unfortunate situation and I wish that there was a better solution that allowed me to truly be off duty on certain nights or weekends. I know an obvious suggestion that people might mention would be communicating with my supervisor on this particular issue but I am a little worried that this might cause some friction between myself and my manager if he senses that I am unhappy with this particular expectation of the job. I feel that it would be easier and clearer for everyone if there was a specific policy that covered this situation (ie the “always on-call staff”), as it shouldn’t be up to me to have to clear up confusion over a pretty important job requirement like this one.

To sum it up: St. Jude as a workplace as a whole would get 4 stars but I can only give 3 stars in my case because I feel that the 24/7/365 on-call expectation isn’t a realistic option, encroaches too much on personal life and should have been communicated clearly to me as a requirement of the position beforehand. 

 If I had truly known about the 24/7/365 on-call expectation beforehand, I would have requested significantly more money (either in the form of a large bump to my yearly salary or as on-call pay, something I currently do not receive) before ever accepting the job. I certainly wouldn’t do it for my present salary and wouldn’t do it for anything less than a six figure salary.

 I know HR does salary surveys for our positions but I highly doubt they are taking into account that some of our IT positions essentially require us to be on-call 24/7/365 whenever they are comparing our positions and salaries to the positions and salaries of other employers. As a result, the salary surveys in some of our cases are almost certainly an apples-to-oranges comparison.

If I leave St. Jude in the future it will almost certainly be because of the 24/7/365 on-call expectation and St. Jude’s lack of clarification on how we can respond to call requests and have work/life balance as well. Long-term, I have a feeling that is probably what I will do, so that I can set appropriate boundaries between work and personal life and so that I don’t have to be married to a cell phone and laptop every night and weekend.

headline: A great cause and a great place to work
pros:
Saint Jude Children's Research Hospital is devoted to research and treatment of catastrophic childhood illness. The big emphasis is cancer, but work is also done on infectious diseases, and sickle-cell anemia. The hospital make sure families never need to pay out of pocket by picking up the costs that insurance doesn't
A big plus of working here is working for such a great cause.
The facilities and infrastructure are first class.
There is an interesting spirit of egalitarianism in some areas. For example, there is only one cafeteria/dining area and it is for everybody from head honchos to the housekeepers to the patients and the families.
cons:
It can be a pretty high pressure environment, but I think that's to be expected.
If you're not involved directly with patient care, it is sometimes hard connect what you're doing with overall cause. 
Recently there's been a lot of turnover in top management, leaving people wondering what will happen next.

headline: Review of the research side of St Jude
pros:
For the research side of St Jude your work environment is typically governed by your principal investigator, however there many common benefits we all receive:

Competitive salary
Strong organizational culture
Great insurance benefits (to cover the employee's medical alone, your contribution is $0)
Strong focus on employee wellness, including gym and counseling plan
Strong focus on career development including paid tuition and seminars to promote growth.
cons: Many people are nervous to move to Memphis, however the city has made great strides in developing a fun and active culture, and this is not a native Memphian writing this.
